To create the perfect collision, I had to implement both the conservation of momentum and the conservation of energy. Let the red ball's mass be \( m_{\text{red}} \), its initial velocity be \( u_{\text{red}} \), and its final velocity be \( v_{\text{red}} \). Similarly, let the blue ball's mass be \( m_{\text{blue}} \), its initial velocity be \( u_{\text{blue}} \), and its final velocity be \( v_{\text{blue}} \). According to the law of conservation of momentum: \[ m_{\text{red}} u_{\text{red}} + m_{\text{blue}} u_{\text{blue}} = m_{\text{red}} v_{\text{red}} + m_{\text{blue}} v_{\text{blue}} \tag{1} \] In this equation, the unknowns are \( v_{\text{red}} \) and \( v_{\text{blue}} \). To solve for these two unknowns, we need a second equation. Fortunately, energy is also conserved in this elastic collision. According to the conservation of kinetic energy: \[ \frac{1}{2} m_{\text{red}} u_{\text{red}}^2 + \frac{1}{2} m_{\text{blue}} u_{\text{blue}}^2 = \frac{1}{2} m_{\text{red}} v_{\text{red}}^2 + \frac{1}{2} m_{\text{blue}} v_{\text{blue}}^2 \tag{2} \] From these two equations, we can solve for \( v_{\text{red}} \) and \( v_{\text{blue}} \). The solutions are: \[ v_{\text{red}} = \frac{m_{\text{red}} - m_{\text{blue}}}{m_{\text{red}} + m_{\text{blue}}} u_{\text{red}} + \frac{2 m_{\text{blue}}}{m_{\text{red}} + m_{\text{blue}}} u_{\text{blue}} \] and \[ v_{\text{blue}} = \frac{m_{\text{blue}} - m_{\text{red}}}{m_{\text{red}} + m_{\text{blue}}} u_{\text{blue}} + \frac{2 m_{\text{red}}}{m_{\text{red}} + m_{\text{blue}}} u_{\text{red}} \]
